newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile Escondida union seeks collective contract.
newsitem.headline: Chile Escondida union seeks collective contract.

text.p: Union leaders at Chile's giant Escondida copper mine said they plan to start collective negotiations and present their demands to the pit's management next month.
Escondida, unlike most Chilean copper mines, does not have a collective contract with its workers.
"We have prepared a collective contract which we will present to workers' assemblies," Hugo Fernandez, president of the pit's only union, told Reuters by telephone from Antofagasta.
The union will hold meetings Tuesday and Saturday to discuss the demands with workers before handing them over to management, said Fernandez.
The union, which was set up several years ago, represents 250 of Escondida's 2,000 miners.
Escondida, the world's largest copper mine, produced 841,361 tonnes of copper last year. It is owned by Australia's Broken Hill Proprietary and RTZ Corp plc.
